Notes: Conclusions may appear under the discussion section
Some disciplines/journals separate conclusions from discussions
Structure varies by discipline, journal, and paper purpose

moves: Restate Aims: Remind readers of study objectives (e.g., 'The aim of the present research was...')
Summarize Findings: Present key results (e.g., 'These experiments confirmed that...')
Suggest Implications: Connect to broader field (e.g., 'The results indicate that...')
Explain Significance: Highlight contributions (e.g., 'This study contributes to...')
Acknowledge Limitations: Address constraints (e.g., 'A major limitation of this study is...')
Provide Recommendations: Future research directions (e.g., 'More research using controlled trials is needed...')
Offer Practice Guidelines: Practical applications (e.g., 'Greater efforts are needed to...')

patterns: Restating aims: Uses past tense, formal language
Recommendations: Often uses modal verbs (could, should, will)
